newsitem.title: SOUTH AFRICA: De Beers diamond profits dazzle.
newsitem.headline: De Beers diamond profits dazzle.

text.p: Diamond giant De Beers Consolidated Mines Ltd posted strong year results on Tuesday as its earnings per share rose to 354 U.S. cents from 259 cents.
The group also increased its dividend by 10.5 percent to 102.7 U.S. cents a share.

Analysts had expected a good set of results following on from a sparkling performance at the half year in August and record sales in 1996 by its Central Selling Organisation (CSO), which controls some 75 percent of the rough-diamond market.
De Beers said diamond demand remained strong with good sales reported at the first two so-called "sights" of 1997, where the CSO sells to a select group of traders.
Market watchers say the firm is also reaping benefits from its investments in other firms like Anglo American Corp of South Africa Ltd and Minorco.
Total combined earnings, including the share of retained associates' earnings, were $1,344 million, up fom $986 million.
This included an exceptional profit of $109 million from the disposal of a portion of its interest in industrial holding firm Johnnic.
Excluding associates', earnings totalled $828 million against $624 million, while the diamond account for the year totalled $803 million compared to $760 million.
De Beers shares rose after the news was announced to a new year high of 159.75 cents before closing down 50 cents on the day at 157.00 on some profit-taking.

De Beers said it had held "constructive" talks with the Russian diamond authorities with a view to resume a contractual relationship following a stand-off late last year which unnerved the world diamond market.
